elements.title: Galileo's middle finger (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Galileo's middle finger (pictured) is considered a secular relic?

elements.title: Boyz Unlimited (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Richard Osman, who wrote "the biggest thing in fiction since Harry Potter", lost confidence in his writing ability after his experience with Boyz Unlimited?

elements.title: Travis Glover (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Green Bay Packers player Travis Glover started at three separate positions along the offensive line during his college football career?

elements.title: Le Touquet (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that even though about 100,000 mines were laid in Le Touquet during World War II, making it the most mined city in France, it was the first resort in northern France to open its beaches after the liberation?

elements.title: Samuel Kummer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that for his first recital as the organist of the restored Frauenkirche in Dresden, Samuel Kummer chose music by Bach, Brahms, and himself?

elements.title: El Salvador was the first country to recognize Manchukuo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that El Salvador was the first country to recognize Manchukuo, apart from Japan?

elements.title: Peggy Pond Church (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that poet Peggy Pond Church became a strong pacifist and a member of the Society of Friends after the Manhattan Project used her home as a place to build nuclear weapons?

elements.title: Anne Griffiths (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that librarian Anne Griffiths was one of the first British women to cross the Antarctic Circle?

elements.title: The Days of '98 Show (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a firearm blank goes off during The Days of '98 Show shootout, startling the audience?
